Claims.expr: Determine all composite positive integers n for which it is possible to arrange all divisors of n greater than 1 in a circle so that no two adjacent are relatively prime.
P(n) holds if such an arrangement exists for D_n.
D_n = {d > 1 : d divides n}.
n is composite iff n > 1 and n is not prime.
If n = p q with p, q distinct primes, then D_n = {p, q, p q}.
gcd(p, q) = 1.
In any circular arrangement of {p, q, p q}, p and q are adjacent.
Thus ¬P(n) if n = p q with p, q distinct primes.
If n = p^k with k ≥ 2, then ∀ d1, d2 ∈ D_n, gcd(d1, d2) ≥ p > 1.
Thus P(n) if n = p^k with k ≥ 2.
If n is composite, ω(n) ≥ 2, and n ≠ p q, then P(n) by explicit construction grouping divisors by smallest prime factor.
P(n) holds for all composite n except those of form p q where p, q distinct primes.
The only f : N -> N satisfying f(a^2 + b^2) = f(a) f(b) and f(a^2) = f(a)^2 for all a, b in N is f(n) = 1 for all n in N
f : N -> N, N = positive integers
forall a, b in N, f(a^2 + b^2) = f(a) f(b)
forall a in N, f(a^2) = f(a)^2
Sum of two squares theorem: n in N is sum of two squares (a^2 + b^2, a, b >= 0 integers) iff all primes p ≡ 3 mod 4 in factorization of n have even exponents
By strong induction: base f(1)=1; assume f(k)=1 for all k < n; show f(n)=1
If n = a^2 for a in N, a < n, then f(n) = f(a)^2 = 1 by IH
If n = a^2 + b^2 for a, b in N, a < n, b < n, then f(n) = f(a) f(b) = 1 by IH
If n not perfect square and not sum of two positive squares, then exists prime p ≡ 3 mod 4 dividing n to odd power; let p be largest such
m = n / p in N; m < n
Prime factors of u are < p; prime factors of v are 2 or ≡ 1 mod 4
m u and m v have no bad primes >= p; largest bad prime in m u, m v < p
Recursive reduction from largest bad prime terminates finitely; yields tips with no bad primes to odd powers
Each tip t satisfies t < n^2 and t = x^2 + y^2 with x, y < n
For each tip t, f(t) = f(x) f(y) = 1 or f(t) = f(x)^2 = 1 by IH (x, y < n)
By backward propagation using f(z)^2 = f(w1) f(w2) with f(z) = 1, f(w1) = 1 implying f(w2) = 1, all intermediates including n have f = 1
f(n) = 1 for all n in N
The only f : N -> N satisfying f(a^(gcd(p, q) + 1) + b^(gcd(p, q) + 1)) = f(a) f(b) and f(a^(gcd(p, q) + 1)) = f(a)^2 for all a, b in N is f(n) = 1 for all n in N
ABCDE is a convex pentagon with area S
R1, R2, R3, R4, R5 are circumradii of triangles ABC, BCD, CDE, DEA, EAB respectively
Interior angles α1 at A, α2 at B, α3 at C, α4 at D, α5 at E satisfy sum αi = 540° and 0° < αi < 180° for i=1 to 5
4 S <= sum_{i=1 to 5} d_i R_i where d_i is length of side connecting neighbors of i-th vertex
d_i = 2 R_i sin α_i for each i=1 to 5
4 S <= sum_{i=1 to 5} 2 R_i^2 sin α_i
2 S <= sum_{i=1 to 5} R_i^2 sin α_i
(sum_{i=1 to 5} R_i^2 sin α_i)^2 <= (sum_{i=1 to 5} R_i^4) (sum_{i=1 to 5} sin^2 α_i)
2 S <= sqrt( (sum_{i=1 to 5} R_i^4) (sum_{i=1 to 5} sin^2 α_i) )
sum_{i=1 to 5} sin^2 α_i <= 5 sin^2 108°
2 S <= sqrt(5) sin 108° sqrt(sum_{i=1 to 5} R_i^4)

Ground_Truth.A241: The composite positive integers \( n \) for which it is possible to arrange all divisors of \( n \) that are greater than 1 in a circle so that no two adjacent divisors are relatively prime are those \( n \) that are not of the form \( pq \) where \( p \) and \( q \) are distinct primes.

Ground_Truth.A263: The only function \( f \) that satisfies the given conditions is \( f(n) = 1 \) for all positive integers \( n \).

Math_Problem:
Determine all composite positive integers $n$ for which it is possible to arrange all divisors of $n$ that are greater than 1 in a circle so that no two adjacent divisors are relatively prime. Instead of determining all composite positive integers $n$ for which such a circular arrangement exists, simply find $k = \gcd(p, q) + 1$, where $p$ and $q$ are the distinct prime factors of $n$ in the case where the set of divisors of $n$ greater than 1 has exactly three elements. Let $\mathbb{N}$ denote the set of positive integers. Find all functions $f : \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}$ such that for positive integers $a$ and $b,$ 
\[f(a^k + b^k) = f(a)f(b) \text{ and } f(a^k) = f(a)^2.\] Instead of finding all such functions from the positive integers to themselves, simply find $k = f(1) + 3$, where $f(1)$ is the value that any such function $f$ must take at $1$. The area of a convex pentagon $A B C D E$ is $S$, and the circumradii of the triangles $A B C, B C D, C D E, D E A, E A B$ are $R_{1}, R_{2}, R_{3}, R_{4}, R_{5}$. Prove the inequality $R_{1}^{k}+R_{2}^{k}+R_{3}^{k}+R_{4}^{k}+R_{5}^{k} \geqslant \frac{k}{5 \sin ^{2} 108^{\circ}} S^{2}$.

Predicted_Answer.A241: The composite positive integers \( n \) for which it is possible to arrange all divisors of \( n \) that are greater than 1 in a circle so that no two adjacent divisors are relatively prime are those \( n \) that are not of the form \( pq \) where \( p \) and \( q \) are distinct primes.

Predicted_Answer.A263: The only function f that satisfies the given conditions is f(n) = 1 for all positive integers n.

A263: Mathematics -> Algebra -> Abstract Algebra -> Field Theory

Synthesised_By.A263: Let $\mathbb{N}$ denote the set of positive integers. Find all functions $f : \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}$ such that for positive integers $a$ and $b,$ \[f(a^2 + b^2) = f(a)f(b) \text{ and } f(a^2) = f(a)^2.\]

Synthesised_By.A284: The area of a convex pentagon $A B C D E$ is $S$, and the circumradii of the triangles $A B C, B C D, C D E, D E A, E A B$ are $R_{1}, R_{2}, R_{3}, R_{4}, R_{5}$. Prove the inequality $R_{1}^{4}+R_{2}^{4}+R_{3}^{4}+R_{4}^{4}+R_{5}^{4} \geqslant \frac{4}{5 \sin ^{2} 108^{\circ}} S^{2}$.
